Location: Horseshoe Bay Ferry Terminal, West Vancouver, British Columbia
SummaryOfEvents: On 08 December 1991, at 12:19 hours, while making a normal approach to the Horseshoe Bay Ferry Terminal, West Vancouver, British Columbia, the ferry "Howe Sound Queen", under the conduct of a trainee master, struck the berth heavily. The striking occurred in daylight with good visibility and calm weather. Several passengers fell and sustained injuries, and several vehicles parked on the ferry's deck were damaged.

In the early hours of 30 November 1991, while on a positioning voyage from Singapore to Cebu City in the Philippines, the Australian registered fishing ship Northern L caught fire. The six crews were enable to fight the fire and abandoned the ship, taking with them an emergency radio and ship’s 406lHz emergency position indicator radio beacon (EPIRB). At about 05:00 hours, explosions were heard coming from the ship, which sank shortly after.  The six survivors had been rescued by the Liberian registered tanker Nagasaki Spirit en route from Dulang, Malaysia to Santa, Indonesia.

Location: in Tees Bay off the east coast of England
SummaryOfEvents:
Stora Korsnas Link I sailed at 11:20 hrs on 31 October 1991 from Gavle for Hartlepool, England. On 5th November 1991 at 06.29 hrs a fire started in the ship's engine room. The C02 fire extinguishing system was activated. At 07:55 hrs it was feared that the fire had spread to the cargo. C02 fire extinguishing was activated to the cargo spaces (holds 1 and 2) and again to the engine room.
At 08:35 hrs, seven crew members were evacuated by helicopter. The ship lay at anchor from 09.15 to 11:20 hrs. At 09:40 hrs a further five crew members were evacuated by helicopter. The vessel was under tow from 11:20 to 15:10 hrs. Towards the end of this period it was noted that the fire had spread to the garage deck.
At 15:10 hrs the ship was again anchored. At 15:50 hrs the remaining crew members were evacuated by helicopter.
During the following four days the ship was on fire, first on the garage deck, later in the accommodation spaces. Since the ship was carrying dangerous cargo (sodium chlorate) she was not permitted to enter port. She was kept under observation and was sprayed with water for cooling from 6th November at 06:55 hrs by the contracted salvage company. On 10th November at about 04:05 hrs a number of violent explosions took place in the vessel, which immediately started to sink.

On 4 October 1991 the Australian flag bulk carrier TNT Carpentaria was on passage from Weipa to Gladstone with a fill cargo of bauxite and drawing a maximum draught of 12.13m. 
At about 17:16 hours Eastern Standard Time, a pilot from the Queensland Coast and Torres Strait Pilot Service boarded the ship about 2.4 miles west of Harrison Rock buoy at the western extreme of the Prince of Wales channel. 
After a brief discussion with the Master, the pilot advised that there was insufficient water in certain parts of the Prince of Wales Channel to allow the ship to make a safe passage. It was decided to wait off the channel until the transmitting tide gauges indicated sufficient under-keel clearance to allow the ship to transit the channel. 
At about 17:36 hours, the pilot ordered the wheel be put hard to port, so as to make a turn on to a reciprocal course to await the tide. 
At about 17:54 hours, the ship grounded 0.7 miles north-west of Harrison Rock at the western end of Sunk Reefs. 
At about 21:03 hours the ship refloated under its own power and the passage to Gladstone was resumed. 
No-one was injured in the incident and there was no pollution.

Nippo Maru completed unloading cargo alongside a pier in Port Himeji (Hyogo Prefecture). It had been scheduled that the ship to be loaded with new cargoes at the same pier. However, as a strong typhoon was approaching there, Nippo Maru decided to take refuge out of the harbour. 
The ship, leaving her holds empty, took abt. 900 tons of sea water ballast in her double bottom tanks and lay outside the harbour at her port anchor, setting a deck hand as Watch Keeper in Port. The ship dragged anchor due to the increasingly forceful South-Eastern wind and stranded on the wave damper blocks placed around the wharf at her stern bottom.

Location: On Unison Reef, Great Barrier Reef
SummaryOfEvents:
On 9 September 1991 the 6710 tonnes deadweight Panamanian registered motor tanker Jovian Loop grounded on Unison Reef in the inner two-way route of the Great Barrier Reef, while on passage from Broome to Townsville with a part cargo of tallow.

The ship was refloated after one hour, without assistance, and continued on its voyage to Townsville. No pollution resulted from the grounding and the ship sustained only minor damage.

Location: Esso Fawley Refinery Marine Terminal on
SummaryOfEvents:
The 1972 built, UK registered motor tanker Esso Mersey was discharging cargo at the Esso Fawley Refinery Marine Terminal on 4 September 1991 when an explosion occurred in the pump room. The products of the explosion passed up through the pump room, burst into the cargo control room, and exited through the forward starboard door at poop deck level. The Chief Officer suffered severe burns from which he later died while an Able Seaman was killed outright in the blast.

The discharge operation ceased immediately and, due to the action taken by ship's staff, only minor leakage in the pump room. Minor fire damage occurred in the pump room with severe blast and fire damage to the cargo control room.

Capsizing and sinking of Derrick Barge 29 (DB29) on 15 August 1991, in the South China Sea while under tow by the tug MV Typhoon.
173 crew members survived the incident and 17 crew members died as a result of the incident. 5 crew members were missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On 26 June 1991 the Manila Transporter sailed from Dampier, Western Australia with a crew of 24 and a cargo of 103.001 metric tonnes of iron ore fines for Port Talbot, Wales.

On 7 July 1991, the Master of the ship broadcast a distress message, stating that the ship was taking water in number 3 hold and that assistance was required. The Norwegian bulk carrier Berica responded to the message and rescued all 24 Filipino crew of the Manila Transporter, who abandoned ship in the lifeboats. The Berica then proceeded on passage as the Manila Transporter was believed to be sinking. 

On 27 July 1991, the Singapore registered ship Algenib encountered the derelict Manila Transporter and attempted salvage operations. However, the Manila Transporter eventually sank in 7 August 1991.

ShipType1: Other Bulk Dry (cement, woodchips, urea and other specialized) Carrier
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On 22 July 1991, the Netherlands flag livestock ship Zebu Express was lying at anchor in Darwin Harbour. The Master and Second Mate had left the ship, the Chief Officer being the Officer in Charge.
In the morning the Chief Engineer and Second Engineer began working in the bow thruster compartment, cleaning the electrical motor of the bow thruster.
Early in the afternoon the Chief Engineer observed the Second Engineer to be in physical difficulty in the lower part of the compartment and raised the alarm. He then made several attempts to assist the Second Engineer, entering the compartment without using a breathing apparatus.
Both the Chief Engineer & Second Engineer collapsed in the lower part of the bow thruster compartment. Attempts to rescue the two men were made by the Assistant Engineer, wearing a self contained compressed air breathing apparatus, but he was unable to effect a rescue.
The bodies of the Chief Engineer and Second Engineer were eventually recovered from the bow thruster compartment by members of the Darwin Fire Service.

SOLASStatus: AIKO MARU: Unknown/unspecified, Yoshu Maru No. 17: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Aiko Maru was navigating through the Bungo Channel taking her course to 326° TB and at her full speed of 13:6 knots. At that time visibility in the sea area restricted by dense fog, but she was not sounding fog signal. 15 minutes before the collision took place, she firstly detected the presence of Yoshu Maru No. 17 by radar 6 miles off bearing 2° on her starboard bow, and secondly, 7 minutes before the collision, 3 miles off bearing 5° on her starboard bow. Thus being in a condition that she could not avoid developing close-quarters situation with Yoshu MAru No. 17, Aiko Maru No. 17 continued to navigate, neither reducing her speed to minimum at which she could be kept on her course nor taking all her way off  if necessary, to collide with Yoshu Maru No. 17.
Yoshu Maru No. 17, which departed port Tokuyama Kudamatu for Port Kochi with fully loaded cargo, was  navigating through the Bungo Channel  taking her course to 142° TB and at her full speed of 11 knots. At that time visibility in the sea area was restricted by dense fog, but the ship was not sounding fog signal. 8 minutes before the collision, Yoshu Maru No. 17 firstly detected the presence of Aiko Maru by radar 3 miles off bearing 9° on her starboard bow. Thus being in a condition that she could not avoid developing close-quarters situation with Aiko Maru, Yoshu Maru No. 17 continued to navigate, neither reducing her speed to the minimum at which  she could be kept on her course nor taking all her way off if necessary, to collide with Aiko Maru

On 1st July 1991, at about 00:25 hours, while down bound in the St. Lawrence River with a cargo of grain, the Great Lakes bulk carrier "Halifax" grounded to the north of the navigation channel, downstream of the Grondines wharf. The ship ran out of the channel in darkness but in conditions of good visibility. The ship suffered considerable bottom damage and lost an anchor, there was no pollution, and there were no injuries.

SOLASStatus: SEASPAN 356: Unknown/unspecified, SEASPAN 393: Unknown/unspecified, SEASPAN RUSTLER: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Fleuve Fraser, Pont de la rue Oak, Vancouver (Colombie-Britannique)
SummaryOfEvents: Le capitaine du remorqueur Seaspan Rustler, qui descendait le bras nord du Fraser en remorquant deux chaland, a voulu faire virer le convoi à l’approche du pont ferroviaire Marpole et le remorqueur a été engagé par sa remorque. Le Seaspan Rustler a  chaviré rapidement et le remorqueur renversé a été entraîné par le courant avec les chalands jusqu'à ce que la remorque  s’enroule autour du pilier de protection  du pylône  sud du pont  de la rue Oak.  Les deux membres de l’équipage se sont hissés sur le pont de l’un  des chalands et ont été promptement secourus par un autre remorqueur.

SOLASStatus: JIN SHAN HAI: Unknown/unspecified, KEKENNI: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
The Chinese motor bulk carrier Jin Shan Hai passed Low Isles at about 00:00 hours Eastern Standard Time, 17 June 1991, on a course of 152° at a speed of approximately 13 knots, while on passage from the port of Gove, Northern Territory, to Gladstone, Queensland, with a part cargo of alumina. The ship was shaping a course for Cairns fairway buoy where the pilot of the Torres Strait and Queensland Coast Pilot Service was to be disembarked.

At the same time the Australian prawn trawler Kekenni was engaged in trawling off Batt Reef steering about 135°, at a speed of about 3 knots.

At about 00:35 hours, the two ships collided in approximate position 16°30.0 South 145°40.2 East, about 26 miles north-north-west of Cairns. The visibility was clear with a calm sea and slight swell. The Kekenni subsequently sank and the three crew took to the trawler's dinghy. 

At 00:42 hours Townsville Marine Communications Station received a message from the trawler Prospector reporting the incident and confirming that the Prospector was proceeding to search for the crew. 
The Master of the Jin Shan Hai was called to the bridge, and the ship turned to render assistance.

The three crew members of the Kekenni were rescued from the dinghy by the Prospector
Apart from minor bruises and abrasions the crew of the Kekenni suffered no injury. The Prospector returned to Cairns with the crew aboard.

At 01:10 hours, the Jin Shan Hai resumed passage for Gladstone.

Location: South-East of Main Duck Island Light, Lake Ontario
SummaryOfEvents:
The Bulk Carrier “Malinska”, with a cargo of 23,929 tonnes of steel coils departed from Hamilton, Ontario, on 12 May 1991 bound for the intermediate port of Sorel, Quebec, and, thence, the sea.
After altering course south of Main Duck Island, approximately 20 miles ssw of Kingston, Ontario, the “Malinska” ran aground at night, about  0.3 mile NW of the Ducks light buoy MM2 .
The ship was extensively damaged, but there was no pollution. 
Visibility, which was variable in fog patches, was about four miles at the time of the occurrence, otherwise, weather conditions were fair with westerly winds at 10 knots.

On 9 May 1991, the Eastern Shell, making her first voyage after a period of lay-up, departed from Sarnia, Ontario, with a consignment of petroleum products for delivery at Parry Sound, Ontario. While negotiating the entrance to the Main Channel, Parry Sound, shortly after sunrise 10 May 1991, the bridge team experienced difficulty in finding and identifying navigation marks in the prevailing bright sunlight conditions. Notwithstanding this problem, the ship proceeded at full speed ahead and contacted the bottom on Knight Shoal. Bridge procedures adapted to the circumstance were not in place nor had the ship's speed been reduced.
The ship was then taken to anchor to assess the situation.

The Canadian tug « Patricia B. McAllister », with a crew of six, left Montreal, Quebec, on 20 April 1991 and was expected at Pictou, Nova Scotia, on the evening of 22 April. At about 05:30 hours, on 22 April, which was approximately 16 hours before her estimated time of arrival, the crew abandoned the rapidly sinking ship into the water. A search was started about 27 hours after the sinking. A first liferaft was sighted about two and one half hours into the search. Five of the six members of the  crew perished.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On 17 April 1991 at 16 :00 hours, the ship arrived at Ulsan. At 16:20 hours the ship anchored at the quarantine anchorage. After completing immigration port formalities the master and nine crew members went ashore. At that time the weather was calm with slight mist, fine rain and slight winds.

At about 20:00 hours, the wind freshened up. At about 21:30 hours, the wind force increased rapidly to force 7 and the sea became rough. The duty officer instructed the engine room to stand-by engines for immediate manoeuvring and instructed the crew to pay out more anchor cable. However, as the ship was shipping heavy sea on deck the crew were unable to proceed to the forecastle. The duty officer also informed the master and the port authorities of the situation.

At 23:05 hours, the ship commenced dragging anchor. The duty officer used the engines to reduce the strain on the cable and to prevent her from drifting towards a shoal to the north of the ship. However, the ship continue to drift. On 18 April 1991 at 05:00 hours, the ship grounded.

At about 07:20 hours, a tug was despatched to the ship. However,  due to tough seas, the tug was unable to come close to the ship. At about 12:00 hours, the duty officer decided to abandon the ship. While preparing to launch the life saving appliances, an able-bodied seaman was washed overboard.
At about 17:00 hours, the remaining crew were evacuated  by helicopter. The ship declared a constructive total loss
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
An explosion followed by a fire occurred on board the Cypriot tanker "Haven" at 12:45 hours on 11 April 1991 off Genoa, Italy. As a result of the explosion the tanker broke in two. The wreck started sinking slowly. In order to limit the impact, Italian Authorities decided to tow the burning wreck towards shallower water west of Genoa.

On 13 April in the morning the towing had to be abandoned due to another explosion. Subsequently the wreck partially sunk, approximately 1.5 nautical miles south of Arenzano, west of Genoa. The fire continued for about 70 hours till the whole ship sunk. A third explosion at 5:30 hours, on 14 April caused a release of oil. In totally 8 or 9 explosions happened. The ship finally sunk at 10:05 hours on 14 April 1991. After the ship sunk major release of oil was observed

Location: SouthWest bound lane of the Dover Strait Traffic Separation Scheme
SummaryOfEvents:
The 26 metre fishing ship WILHEMINA J, left Portsmouth on 9th April 1991 to trawl for scallops in the English Channel in the vicinity of fishing grounds known as Horseshoe Bank. She had a crew of six. At approximately 02:00 hours on 10 April Wilhelmina J was in collision, in thick fog, with MV Zulfikar, a 142 metre 8714 ton Cyprus-registered cargo ship. The collision occurred about three miles west of the termination of the southwest bound lane of the Dover strait Traffic Separation Scheme.
An extensive search was mounted but it ended without survivors or bodies.
On the 2nd July 1991 two bodies were found inside the wreck, but the other four crew members were not found.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: Bay of Long Point, Lac Erié
SummaryOfEvents: On 18th March 1991 just before 13:20 hours, the Canadian Natinonal coast Guard vessel GRIFFON was exiting Long Point Bay when she was in a collision with the Canadian fishing boat "Captain K", which was returning to port. Visibility was bad, due to fog. The fishing boat sank almost immediately, and the bodies of three crew members were later found in the wreck when the Captain K was being towed back into the bay. The  "Captain K", very badly damaged, was declared a total loss. The GRIFFON sustained only minor scrapes.

On 03 March 1991, the Canadian-registered tug "SEA EAGLE II" and barge "ST. MARYS
CEMENT II" were en route from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, to Tampa, Florida, for 
dry-docking. The barge was empty, but the residual and gases of the previous cargo of
Naphtha 2 were still in the tanks. The vessel was carrying a provisional gas-freeing certificate and was gas-freeing in transit. At approximately 16:24 hrs , in a heavy sea and swell and with distant electrical activity on the horizon, the gas exiting at the No. 4 aft port tank hatch caught fire.

ShipType1: Other Bulk Dry (cement, woodchips, urea and other specialized) Carrier

SummaryOfEvents:
On 30 January 1991, the bulk carrier “Orjen”, in ballast condition in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, suffered ice blockage of the main engine cooling-water intakes. To provide for continued engine cooling, the crew arranged to pump ballast water from a hold and to replenish the water using a second ballast pump. During the night of 30/31 January, the amount of ballast water in the hold exceeded the allowable limit. On the morning of 31 January, a bulkhead separating this hold from an adjoining one collapsed.

The board determined that the level of water in the No.7 hold was not monitored effectively and the bulkhead collapsed when hydrostatic pressure, caused by a ballast water level in excess of the recommended maximum, exceeded the bulkhead’s strength and the allowed limit.
